ScenarioEntry.name: Absent Finding Not in Case
ScenarioEntry.Description: User asserts an absent finding that has not been mentioned as explicitly absent in the case

MessageEntry.Message: The absence of <concept> is not important for solving this case.
The absence of <concept> is not important for solving this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Absent Finding Observed at Low Power
ScenarioEntry.Description: You have stated an absence of finding at power that is generally considered to low to really observe it.

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct that <concept> is not in this case, but absence of <concept> is generally determined at a higher power.
You are correct that <concept> is not in this case, but absence of <concept> is generally determined at a higher power.

ScenarioEntry.name: Absent Finding Should be Present
ScenarioEntry.Description: A user asserts an absence of a finding, that is in fact authored as present in the case.

MessageEntry.Message: Actually, <concept> is an important feature that is present in this case.
Actually, <concept> is an important feature that is present in this case.
You can generally observe <concept> here.
This is an example of <concept>.
Delete the absence of <concept>, and identifiy that it is in fact present.

ScenarioEntry.name: Absent Finding is Not Important
ScenarioEntry.Description: This finding was authored as explicitly absent in the case, however it is not an important factor in coming up with a diagnosis

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct that <concept> is not present in this case. However, in the context of this domain and case, the absence of this finding is not significant in deducing the correct diagnosis.
You are correct that <concept> is not present in this case. However, in the context of this domain and case, the absence of this finding is not significant in deducing the correct diagnosis.

ScenarioEntry.name: Incorrect Absent Finding Location
ScenarioEntry.Description: While the finding is indeed absent. Its absence needs to be observed at a different location on the slide

MessageEntry.Message: You are right that <concept> is absent, but you can generally evaluate the absence of <concept> in another location.
You are right that <concept> is absent, but you can generally evaluate the absence of <concept> in another location.
This is the general area where you can see <concept>
This is the area where you would generally observe <concept>.
As you can see, <concept> is not there, and its absence is significant in this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Attribute Not Valid
ScenarioEntry.Description: A given attribute is not used to describe a given finding according the domain ontology. Ex: moderate blister

MessageEntry.Message: In the context of this domain, <concept> is not a valid qualifier of <feature>.
Remove <concept> quality from the description of <feature>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Attribute Set Not Valid
ScenarioEntry.Description: In the context of domain ontology a given set of attributes cannot simultaneously describe a given finding. Those attributes may be valid if put in as a separate finding Ex: [subepidermal blister, intraepidermal] VS [subepidremal blister] and [inraepidermal blister] concept

MessageEntry.Message: In the context of this domain, <concept> in conjunction with <finding> is not a valid finding that is understood by the system. However it may be a valid evidence if it is asserted along with another instance of <feature>.
Remove <concept> quality from the description of <feature>.
You may also try to assert another instance of <feature> qualified with <concept> attribute.

ScenarioEntry.name: Attribute Value is Incorrect
ScenarioEntry.Description: This scenario occurse when a selected attribute has a category s.a. QUANTITY and you pick a wrong value. Ex: user picks incorrect QUANTITY.

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct to evaluate <attribute> of <feature>, however <concept> is not the best way to describe <attribute> in this case.
Remove <concept> quality from the description of <feature>, and assert correct <attribute>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Attribute is Incorrect
ScenarioEntry.Description: In the context of this case, a given an attribute is not the best way to describe a finding.

MessageEntry.Message: In the context of this case, <concept> is not the best way to describe <feature>
Remove <concept> quality from the description of <feature>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Attribute is Not Important
ScenarioEntry.Description: The user was more specific then is required by case and described a finding even further. Ex: subepidermal blister is required by case, but user puts in subepidermal blister extend beyound ...

MessageEntry.Message: While <concept> might be an important quality of <feature> in a different context, it is unnecessary in this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Incorrect Attribute Location
ScenarioEntry.Description: This scenario occures when a feature's location that was initially identified correctly is no longer valid once it was described further. Ex: isolated neutrophils and neutrophilic infiltrate share the same feature and location maybe valid, however once one of them is refined, the resulting finding may reside in incorrect location.

MessageEntry.Message: While <feature> can be found in this location, <finding> cannot be observed here.
Remove <concept> quality from the description of <feature>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Diagnosis Became Inconsistent
ScenarioEntry.Description: User identifies a piece of evidence that does not support a diagnosis asserted earlier.

MessageEntry.Message: The diagnosis of <concept> is not supported by all of the evidence identified in this case now.
There are some identified findings that do not support <concept>.
The following findings generally do not support <concept>. Findings: <findings>
Delete the diagnosis of <concept> because not all of the identified findings support it.

ScenarioEntry.name: Diagnosis Doesn't Have Enough Evidence
ScenarioEntry.Description:
If reasoner's diagnostic mode is set to 'absolute', then you can't truely call a diagnosis until you have sufficient evidence to back it.
##SimpleDiagnosticReasoner.diagnoses.inference.mode=absolute##

MessageEntry.Message: You do not yet have sufficient evidence to diagnose this case as <concept>.
Either delete <concept> or identify additional evidence that supports <concept>.
The diagnosis, <concept>, is generally supported by <findings>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Diagnosis Doesn't Match All Findings
ScenarioEntry.Description: One or more of the identifed findings does not fit the proposed diagnosis.

MessageEntry.Message: The proposed diagnosis, <concept>, does not match all of the identified findings in this case.
There are some identified findings that do not support <concept>.
The following findings generally do not support <concept>. Findings: <findings>
Delete the diagnosis of <concept> because not all of the identified findings support it.

ScenarioEntry.name: Diagnosis is Correct
ScenarioEntry.Description: This is a marker state and doesn't have any messages. It identifies correct Dx for the case to set it apart from the correct Dx at a given time given a set of evidence

ScenarioEntry.name: Diagnosis is Correct But Not Supported
ScenarioEntry.Description: User enters correct diagnosis for this case, but it does not seem to be supported by the evidence

MessageEntry.Message: Although <concept> is a correct diagnosis for this case, it doesn't seem to be supported by all of the identified findings.
Although <concept> is a correct diagnosis for this case, it doesn't seem to be supported by all of the identified findings.

ScenarioEntry.name: Diagnosis is Supported But Not Goal
ScenarioEntry.Description: Diagnosis is supported by evidence, yet it is not a correct diagnosis in this case (not a goal). This state does not have any messages associated with it

ScenarioEntry.name: Diagnosis is Too General
ScenarioEntry.Description: Diagnosis is to general to be useful.

MessageEntry.Message: The diagnosis <concept> is too general to be useful.
Remove <concept>

ScenarioEntry.name: Diagnosis is Too Specific
ScenarioEntry.Description: You have a diagnosis which is more specific then what case describes

MessageEntry.Message: The diagnosis <concept> is correct, however it is more specific than the evidence suggests in this case.
The diagnosis <concept> is correct, however it is more specific than the evidence suggests in this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Diagnosis while No Findings
ScenarioEntry.Description: Diagnosis is asserted while no findings are given

MessageEntry.Message: You have not provided any evidence yet. It is too early to specify a diagnosis.
You should either add evidence that supports <concept>, or remove it.

ScenarioEntry.name: Case Has More Diagnoses to Consider
ScenarioEntry.Description: This case has several differential diagnoses and you didn't list all of them

MessageEntry.Message: There are more diagnoses to consider before you can sign out this case.
<concept> has all of the expected features: <findings>. This would be one reasonable diagnosis in this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Case Has More Findings to Consider
ScenarioEntry.Description: There is still some evidence that should be identified

MessageEntry.Message: There is still some additional evidence in this case that should be identified before you can sign out this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Case Needs Diagnosis to Finish
ScenarioEntry.Description: You are trying to finish a case without asserting a single diagnosis.

MessageEntry.Message: You need to assert a diagnosis to be able to sign out this case.
Please assert a diagnosis that matches the evidence in this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Case Needs Refined Findings
ScenarioEntry.Description: While you have already added a correct diagnosis, some evidence that you've found still needs to be specified (refined)

MessageEntry.Message: Some of the evidence identified in this case has not been fully specified. You need to fully describe all of your findings to sign out this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Case Solved
ScenarioEntry.Description: You are done with this case! All of the required findings, hypotheses and diagnoses have been identifed in the case.

MessageEntry.Message: You have FINISHED this case! You can now procede to the next case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding Not in Case
ScenarioEntry.Description: An asserted finding was not authored for a given a case and is either absent or diagnostically irrelevant.

MessageEntry.Message: <concept> is not a prominent feature in this case.
<concept> is not a prominent feature in this case and should be removed.
Delete <concept>

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding Not in Case but Supports Diagnosis
ScenarioEntry.Description: Finding is not in case, but can supports an earlier asserted diagnosis

MessageEntry.Message: <concept> is not a prominent feature in this case, but you can sometimes see <concept> in cases of <diagnosis>.
<concept> is not a prominent feature in this case and should be removed.
Delete <concept>

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding Observed at Low Power
ScenarioEntry.Description: The asserted finding is correct, but generally should be obersved at higher power

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct that <concept> is present in this case, but it is generally observed at <power> power.
You are correct that <concept> is present in this case, but it is generally observed at <power> power.

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding Should be Absent
ScenarioEntry.Description: The asserted finding was in fact authored as explicitly absent in this case.

MessageEntry.Message: Actually... there is no significant <concept> in this location, and the absence of <concept> is an important clue in this case.
Actually... there is no significant <concept> in this location, and the absence of <concept> is an important clue in this case.
Delete the feature <concept> and mention its absence in the case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding is Not Important
ScenarioEntry.Description: Finding is in case, but not important for inferring diagnosis

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct that <concept> is present in this case. However, in the context of this domain and case, <concept> in this location is not significant in deducing the correct diagnosis.
You are correct that <concept> is present in this case. However, in the context of this domain and case, <concept> in this location is not significant in deducing the correct diagnosis.

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding is Too General
ScenarioEntry.Description: Finding is way too general

MessageEntry.Message: The finding <concept> is too general to be useful in solving this case. Please identify a more specific concept.
You should either specify <concept> further, or delete it.

ScenarioEntry.name: Incorrect Finding Location
ScenarioEntry.Description: The asserted finding is indeed present in this case, however it is was asserted at Incorrect Location.

MessageEntry.Message: There is <concept> present, but not where you have pointed in the image. See if you can find where.
This is the general area where you can see <concept>.
This is the area with <concept>.
This is an area that shows <concept> particularly well.

ScenarioEntry.name: No Such Concept in Domain
ScenarioEntry.Description: This state is impossible to encounter since the tutor's user interface restricts which concepts can be asserted to only concepts in the domain. This state is reserved for cases where user interface would be more open ended.

MessageEntry.Message: The concept, <concept>, is not typically considered an important concept in the current domain. Although it may be identified in this case, it generally does not pose a factor in determining the correct diagnosis in this domain.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Absent Finding
ScenarioEntry.Description: There is an important finding that is absent in this case. Absence of this finding is an important factor in coming to a correct diagnosis.

MessageEntry.Message: There's something important to recognize here.
This is an area where you can say something about <feature>.
In this case, there is NO <feature> and that's an important thing to recognize. Be as specific as is appropriate for this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Another Attribute
ScenarioEntry.Description: You already started to specify some feature (added an attribute), but you have to go a bit further w/ your description (add another attribute)

MessageEntry.Message: You have already started to further specify <feature>, however there is more to say about it.
You need to add addtional qualities to further specify <feature>. Some possible qualities are: <potential_attributes> .
In the context of this case <finding> is the best way to describe this feature.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Attribute
ScenarioEntry.Description: Need to specify the finding further (add an attribute) to make it a more meaningful diagnostic evidence.

MessageEntry.Message: You are correct to mention <feature> in this case. However you should describe or specify it further to make it a meaningful evidence.
You are correct to mention <feature> in this case. However you should describe or specify it further to make it a meaningful evidence.
To further describe or specify <feature> you need to add qualities to it. Some possible qualities are: <potential_attributes> .
In the context of this case <finding> is the best way to describe this feature.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Diagnosis
ScenarioEntry.Description: You should now add a diagnosis to a case.

MessageEntry.Message: <concept> has all of the expected features: <findings>. This would be one reasonable diagnosis in this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Finding
ScenarioEntry.Description: There is an important finding that should be identified on the slide, It is an important factor in coming to a correct diagnosis

MessageEntry.Message: There's something important to recognize here.
This is an area where you can see <feature>. See if you can find where.
This is the area of <feature>
This is an area that shows <feature> particularly well.
This is an example of <feature>.
You should put <feature> as evidence. Be as specific as is appropriate for this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Hypothesis
ScenarioEntry.Description: Given a set of asserted findings there is a hypothesis that can be asserted.

MessageEntry.Message: There are more hypotheses you should consider in this case.
Based on histology alone, a reasonable hypothesis here would be <concept>, because it fits well with the findings that you've identified.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Similar Absent Finding
ScenarioEntry.Description: When you need to specify absent finding and similar finding or lack of it was already mentioned

MessageEntry.Message: You have already mentioned <sibling>, however there is another kind of <feature> that is important in this case.
This is an area where you can say something about <feature>.
In this case, there is NO <feature> and that's an important thing to recognize. Be as specific as is appropriate for this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: Missing Similar Finding
ScenarioEntry.Description: While you have already identified one instance of finding there is another instance of similar finding that should be identified,

MessageEntry.Message: There's something important to recognize here.
You have already mentioned <sibling>, however there is another kind of <feature> that is important in this case.
This is the area of another kind of <feature>
This is an area that shows <feature> particularly well.
This is an example of <feature>.
You should put <feature> as evidence. Be as specific as is appropriate for this case.

ScenarioEntry.name: No Diagnoses Yet
ScenarioEntry.Description: You already specified all findings and hypothesis. You should now start comming up with a potential diagnosis.

MessageEntry.Message: You should be able to make a diagnosis at this point. Click on the "D" button and select a hypothesis to move down into the diagnosis space.

ScenarioEntry.name: No Findings Yet
ScenarioEntry.Description: No findings have been identified yet.

MessageEntry.Message: There are important visual cues that you should look for. Click first on the F button and then click on a visual cue in the image.

ScenarioEntry.name: No Hypotheses Yet
ScenarioEntry.Description: Now that all findings have been identified you should start forming a hypothesis.

MessageEntry.Message: At this point, you should probably start trying to think about what this could be.
Click on the H button and select a hypothesis.

ScenarioEntry.name: Hypothesis Became Inconsistent
ScenarioEntry.Description: Evidence set got changed, and hypothesis became inconsistant.

MessageEntry.Message: The hypothesis, <concept>, is not supported by evidence identified in this case now.
The hypothesis, <concept>, is not supported by all of the evidence identified in this case now.
Findings <findings> contradict hypothesis <concept>.
Delete the hypothesis of <concept> because not all of the identified findings support it.

ScenarioEntry.name: Hypothesis Contradicts Some Findings
ScenarioEntry.Description:
Hypothesis contradicts some asserted evidence. This state only applies If reasoner hypotheses mode is set to 'all'. That is asserted hypothesis must be satisfied by ALL evidence asserted by user.
##SimpleDiagnosticReasoner.hypotheses.inference.mode=all##

MessageEntry.Message: The proposed hypothesis <concept> does not match ALL of the identified findings in this case.
The proposed hypothesis <concept> does not match ALL of the identified findings in this case.
Findings <findings> contradict hypothesis <concept>.
Delete hypothesis <concept>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Hypothesis Doesn't Match Any Findings
ScenarioEntry.Description: You have not asserted any finding that supports this hypothesis

MessageEntry.Message: <concept> might be a reasonable hypothesis, but you should have at least one finding in it's favor first.
Delete the hypothesis of <concept> because you don't have any supportive findings for it, or try to find at least one finding that supports it.

ScenarioEntry.name: Hypothesis is Too General
ScenarioEntry.Description: Asserted hypothesis is to general to be useful

MessageEntry.Message: The hypothesis <concept> is too general to be useful.
Please remove <concept>

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding Doesn't Refute Hypothesis
ScenarioEntry.Description: Finding doesn't refute hypothesis in a sense that it in fact supports it.

MessageEntry.Message: Actually, <finding> supports <hypothesis>.
Delete the refute link between <finding> and <hypothesis> or replace it with a support link.

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding No Longer Refutes Hypothesis
ScenarioEntry.Description: This is usually happens when attribute is removed from a finding. This may make a finding no longer refute the hypothesis,

MessageEntry.Message: Finding <finding> no longer refutes hypothesis <hypothesis>
Delete the refute link between <finding> and <hypothesis>.

ScenarioEntry.name: No Evidence that Finding Refutes Hypothesis
ScenarioEntry.Description:
If refute link is explicit as oppose to not-support, then this is thrown whene finding doesn't necessary refute hypothesis.
##SimpleDiagnosticReasoner.refute.inference.mode=refute##

MessageEntry.Message: <finding> does not necessarily refute <hypothesis>. While it does not support this hypothesis, it does not refute it either.
Remove the refute link between <finding> and <hypothesis>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding Doesn't Support Hypothesis
ScenarioEntry.Description: Finding doesn't explicitly support hypothesis.

MessageEntry.Message: Finding <finding> doesn't explicitly support <hypothesis>.
Delete the support link between <finding> and <hypothesis>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding No Longer Supports Hypothesis
ScenarioEntry.Description: After you specified a finding futher, hypothesis is no longer supported.

MessageEntry.Message: Finding <finding> no longer supports hypothesis <hypothesis>.
Delete the support link between <finding> and <hypothesis>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Finding's Parent Supports Hypothesis
ScenarioEntry.Description: While a more specific finding does not support this hypothesis, its parent feature does.

MessageEntry.Message: Finding <finding> doesn't support <hypothesis>, however <parent> does.
Delete the support link between <finding> and <hypothesis>.

ScenarioEntry.name: Removed Correct Concept
ScenarioEntry.Description: Some concept was removed while correct. This is a state that serves as a marker and should not have any messages
